 >I have a pile of ID badges and lanyards to recycle. After a busy few weeks on the conference circuit
column12: here are a few things that caught my attention. And the first and most important did not so much catch my attention as terrify me. >\n >Cyber attacks are rising ever further up the list of reasons for fear. At this point
column13: they arguably head it. At the annual Sibos conference
column14: a huge jamboree for everyone involved in the mechanics of making finance work
column15: cyber defence was crowding out almost all other concerns. The last time I went to Sibos
column16: three years ago
column17: everyone was talking about blockchain technology and bitcoin. Cyber defence was almost nowhere. Bitcoin's price continues to rise
column18: but defence against cyber crime now floods out everything. Despite the interest (and this is the only point I can find from all of this)
column19: it seems hard to identify a way to make money from this. There has been a cyber security ETF (with the predictable ticker symbol HACK) since late in 2014
column20: and it has been lagging the S&P since then. So there is money to be made by finding a company that can successfully combat cyber crime: >\n >A poll of Sibos participants asked them what kept them awake at night the most. Nobody mentioned China
column21: and only one per cent mentioned the euro (so this might be the time to short China and the eurozone). US politics perhaps predictably came first on 43 per cent; cyber crime was next at 33 per cent.  >\n >The numerous cyber crime events were packed out. Not surprisingly: according to Microsoft
column22: some 70 per cent of businesses expect to be attacked this year. Speaker after speaker urged companies to practise \"cyber hygiene\" (which is a thing now
column23: apparently). And the concern is that the securities industry
column24: rather than the payments system
column25: could become a prime target. Bond issuance and trading is being digitalised
column26: and this creates more opportunities for fraud
column27: such as selling fake bonds.  >\n >There are many ways in which a focused cyber attack could become a systemic incident. If the repo market were to crash (rather as it did in 2008)
column28: then the repercussions could be systemic. Or any successful attempt to pull money directly out of accounts could wound trust in the banking system and send everyone to the ATM.  >\n >The risk of cyber attacks also makes companies harder to manage
column29: as more than half of cyber fraud is committed from inside companies. Cyber attackers look for the weakest link
column30: which is likely to be a person
column31: rather than a string of code. And hackers can also benefit from finding the weakest link in terms of common sense
column32: rather than moral fibre. One Microsoft adage is that in every organisation
column33: there is always at least one employee who clicks on every link — and thus opens the entire company to malware
column34: ransomware or whatever. >\n >Dealing with this issue requires great recruitment
column35: and great management if a company is not to lose its ability to talk to itself. Regulators now want to see more data trails
column37: while the increasing use of the \"internet of things\" creates more threats.  >\n >A secure solution will also require some serious game theory. Information technology is generally thought of as a source of competitive advantage
column38:
and companies certainly do not want to reveal confidential data to competitors. But the risks of systemic damage are so great that companies will have to collaborate on this.  >
 >Small wonder that Sibos drafted in an admiral from the US Navy to discuss the threats. Fighting cyber crime will require almost military discipline and strategy. And there are no precedents to guide it. >

 >Frankfurt-bound >
 >Another survey at Sibos might raise alarm in London. Delegates were asked to name which city would supplant London as a financial centre. "None" was an option. And yet the clear winner
column40: was Frankfurt. >\n >Germany's financial capital still has an image problem. Once the results were on the screen
column41:
several people started joking loudly that it must be because of the great Frankfurt nightlife. But that combination should be even more concerning. Nobody denies that London is a great and exciting city (at least for those who can afford it): but many still expect dowdy Frankfurt to overtake it.  >

 >NORA and the Python >
 >I am usually wary of acronyms
column42: but Nora is tugging at my heartstrings. It stands for Non-Obvious Relationship Awareness
column43: a name originally coined for a data-mining technology for finding relationships between people. Developed by Systems Research and Development (now part of IBM) for the Las Vegas gaming industry
column44: it helped casinos detect relationships between cheats
column45: and was subsequently used to probe deep into organised crime.  >Back in 2002
column46: its backers were saying: > \"It will tell you that the Drug Enforcement Agency's agent's college roommate's ex-wife's current husband is the drug lord.\"  >\n >Now
column48: chief technology officer of Fortress Investment Group
column49: suggests that the alpha in public data is in finding relationships. Finding patterns in the data that are not obvious is critical. Getting hold of data these days is easy; all the advantage that one investor can gain over another is in minding it to form a \"data mosaic\" and find more non-obvious relationships. \"How do you increase your Nora?\" >\n >He was speaking on a panel I chaired at MSCI's risk management conference in the US
column50: and it is obvious that everyone else — not just the technologists — agreed with him. Beating the market is ever harder
column51: you can only expect to do it regularly with an advantage in information. And so active investment management has become a job of scraping information from every source
column52: pouring it all down a funnel
column53: and hoping your Nora is high enough to spot something nobody else has seen. That way you can make money.  >\n >If you really care about Nora
column54: you can put a python down the funnel. Python is one of the most popular data-mining tools
column57: to complain that \"I thought a python was a snake\". Pythons have
column59: helped to turn information that was formerly too dense into something that can make money. >\n >Note that this technology is not about finding patterns in the market — that mine may finally have been mined to exhaustion
column60: with some claiming to have found as many as 6m separate factors. It is also not about collecting data in the first place
column61:
although many fund groups are investing in this. This is just about a technological arms race to raise Nora and find some previously invisible moneymaking edge. >

column6: bodyXML:" > >The most backhanded compliment you can achieve is to be blamed or credited for anything good or bad that happens when you happen to be around. It’s a fate often suffered by the euro. This month
column7: Free Lunch has noticed a few such cases and would like to offer a fairer interpretation. >\n >A new academic  >paper on fiscal austerity > after the global financial crisis is interpreted by  >Matt O’Brien > at the Washington Post as showing that “the euro really has been a doomsday device for turning recessions into depressions”. column16: it is easy to show arithmetically that cutting deficits too fast can make debt problems worse rather than better — and what House and colleagues demonstrate is that this seems to have been the case in practice. But that is the opposite of an indictment against the euro. It rather exonerates the single currency from blame for the disastrous growth experience of many eurozone countries — because that disaster was caused by unforced policy choices by leaders
column17: to which alternatives existed. This study is aligned with  >previous studies > that show how much better eurozone economies could have fared with better policies that were at hand
